english: polite; courteous; formal; stand on ceremony

etymology.description: 客 ‘guest’ + 气 ‘air; manner’ ⇒ ‘guest-like manner’ = polite, ceremonious; stand on ceremony.
etymology.interpretation: Combines the idea of a guest with one’s bearing to describe courteous, restrained behavior. Often appears in the set phrase 别客气 to tell someone not to be overly formal.
etymology.simplification: 氣 → 气: simplified by adopting an ancient/abbreviated form that evokes ‘air/breath’ and reduces strokes; 客 unchanged.

examples.chinese: 别客气，请随便坐(別客氣，請隨便坐)。
examples.english: Don’t be formal—please make yourself at home.

examples.chinese: 他对客人很客气，说话很有礼貌(他對客人很客氣，說話很有禮貌)。
examples.pinyin: Tā duì kèrén hěn kèqi, shuōhuà hěn yǒu lǐmào.
examples.english: He is very polite to guests and speaks courteously.

examples.chinese: 老板对新同事一点也不客气，直接指出问题(老闆對新同事一點也不客氣，直接指出問題)。
examples.pinyin: Lǎobǎn duì xīn tóngshì yìdiǎn yě bù kèqi, zhíjiē zhǐchū wèntí.
examples.english: The boss wasn’t polite to the new colleague and pointed out problems directly.
